1.brief: properly, instrumental music; by implication, a poem set to notes
Asaph, the name of three Israelites, and of the family of the first

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
to station, in various applications (literally or figuratively)
a stated assemblage (specifically, a concourse, or generally, a family or crowd)
strength; as adjective, mighty; especially the Almighty (but used also of any deity)
properly, the nearest part, i.e. the center, whether literal, figurative or adverbial (especially with preposition)

to judge, i.e. pronounce sentence (for or against); by implication, to vindicate or punish; by extenssion, to govern; passively, to litigate (literally or figuratively)

2.brief: as far (or long, or much) as, whether of space (even unto) or time (during, while, until) or degree (equally with)
properly, extent (of time); but used only adverbially (especially with other particle prefixes), when (either relative or interrogative)
to judge, i.e. pronounce sentence (for or against); by implication, to vindicate or punish; by extenssion, to govern; passively, to litigate (literally or figuratively)
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
to lift, in a great variety of applications, literal and figurative, absolute and relative

3.brief: to judge, i.e. pronounce sentence (for or against); by implication, to vindicate or punish; by extenssion, to govern; passively, to litigate (literally or figuratively)
properly, dangling, i.e. (by implication) weak or thin
to be (causatively, make) right (in a moral or forensic sense)

4.brief: to slip out, i.e. escape; causatively, to deliver
properly, dangling, i.e. (by implication) weak or thin
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
to snatch away, whether in a good or a bad sense

5.brief: not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to separate mentally (or distinguish), i.e.(generally) understand
to walk (in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively)
to waver; by implication, to slip, shake, fall
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)

6.brief: gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
thou and thee, or (plural) ye and you
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
an elevation, i.e. (adj.) lofty (compar.); as title, the Supreme
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)

7.brief: ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
to die (literally or figuratively); causatively, to kill
properly, united, i.e. one; or (as an ordinal) first
a head person (of any rank or class)
to fall, in a great variety of applications (intransitive or causative, literal or figurative)

8.brief: to rise (in various applications, literal, figurative, intensive and causative)
